Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: The child has been promised a Nintendo, and the parent should purchase it
Expectation2: Fix bugs and troubleshoot issues reported by users or QA
Situation2: A production outage traces back to a defect in their code and customers cannot access the service
Story: I stare at the blinking cursor on my screen, heart pounding as Slack notifications pile up. The production outage is my fault—a bug I missed, now locking out thousands of users. My manager’s message is terse: “Need you on this ASAP.” I know what’s expected. I’m the one who has to fix it, no matter how late it gets. But then I hear my child’s excited footsteps. “Did you get the Nintendo, Dad?” Their eyes are wide with hope. I’d promised, after all. I want to keep that promise, to see their face light up, to be the parent who provides not just stability, but joy. But the outage means I might be working all night, and the money I’d set aside for the Nintendo might have to go toward extra childcare if this keeps happening. I feel the weight of both worlds pressing in—my child’s trust, my team’s reliance, the need to be present at home and indispensable at work. My hands tremble as I hover over the keyboard, torn between two urgent needs, knowing I can’t give both what they deserve.
